The widening of nostrils during breathing – it results from increased effort, and is a sign ofdifficulty in breathing.

A rubber tube inserted through the nostril that reaches to the opening of the throat to allowair to pass.

Insertion of a needle into the chest wall to relieve the pressure of a tension pneumothorax.

A water, glucose, and salt mixture given by mouth or nasogastric tube to dehydrated patientsto replace fluid losses.

Describes a person’s relationship to the surrounding world, including the ability to accuratelyidentify one’s own name and location, as well as the current time and date.

A plastic device inserted through the mouth that reaches to the opening of the throat toprevent the tongue from blocking the airway and allows air to pass.

A formula used to estimate the amount of IV fluid needed for resuscitation of a burn patientover the first 24 hours after the burn. It is: 4 ml fluid X weight in kilograms X total burn surfacearea. Half should be given over the first 8 hours, and half over the next 16 hours.

Tapping on the chest wall to assess the lungs. The quality of the sound on tapping may indicatefluid or air in the lungs.

A critical build-up of fluid in the sac around the heart (the pericardium) that compresses theheart and interferes with normal pumping of blood to the body, leading to shock.

Equipment meant to be worn by a person to protect from infection or injury. This can includegloves, goggles, and protective clothing such as aprons or fluid resistant gowns.

Abnormal fluid collection around the lung that can cause difficulty in breathing and even lungcollapse. Common causes include tuberculosis and other infections, heart failure and cancer.

Air in the space between the lungs and the chest wall (pleural space) that causes the lung tocollapse.

Blood clot travelling to and blocking the vessels of the lungs. The most common source is the legs.

Device that detects oxygen saturation (the percentage of red blood cells saturated withoxygen).

A virus that is transmitted through animal bites that affects the brain and nerves and can causealtered mental status.

Pain that occurs when releasing pressure on the abdomen (as opposed to when pressing onthe abdomen).

Time-sensitive interventions performed in an attempt to manage life-threatening conditions.

The visible pulling in of tissues between the ribs or around the collarbones with strainedinspiration. Retractions are a sign of serious difficulty in breathing.

An approach to asking key history findings for all patients. SAMPLE stands for: S – Signs andSymptoms, A – Allergies, M – Medications, P – Past history, L – Last oral intake, E – Eventssurrounding the illness or injury.

Also called convulsions or fits. Abnormal electrical activity in the brain, often seen as alteredmental status with abnormal repetitive movements. Seizures may be a primary condition ormay be caused by infection, injury, toxins or chemical balance problems.

A state where organs do not get enough blood and oxygen (poor perfusion), leading to organsnot working properly.

An easy way to check hydration status in children by pinching the skin, usually on the abdomen.Well-hydrated skin should return to normal in less than 2 seconds.

A high pitched sound on breathing in that is caused by swelling or a physical obstruction ofthe upper airway.

A wound in the chest wall that allows air in and out of the chest cavity, indicating an openpneumothorax.

Occurs when a pneumothorax causes sufficient pressure inside the chest cavity that bloodvessels collapse (reducing the amount of blood that can return to the heart, and the heartcannot fill or pump enough blood to maintain perfusion of the organs).

Describes a change in the position of the trachea to either side of midline, a finding sometimesassociated with tension pneumothorax.

The trauma primary survey is another term for the ABCDE approach in injured patients. Itincludes initial assessment of an injured person and management of all immediately life-threatening injuries, in order of priority. The primary survey consists of the ABCDE: Airway,Breathing, Circulation, Disability and Exposure.

The head-to-toe (front and back) examination of the trauma patient that includes taking aSAMPLE history. The purpose of this survey is to identify and treat all injuries, with prioritygiven to any hidden life-threatening conditions that were missed by the primary survey.

Sitting upright with neck extended but leaning slightly forward with hands on knees. Peoplewith severe difficulty in breathing will often sit in this position.

A whistling sound made when breathing out due to inflammation in the lungs, suggestive oflower airway swelling.
